The more I think about this, the more it feels like using a builtin aggregate expression within a lambda function doesn't really semantically make sense. I think we could theoretically do it but the example here isn't technically functional so it feels wrong. e.g there is nothing passed into the lambda that would tell each invocation where the last one left off.
I think that if we wanted to support aggregations over collections, we'd want to do it with some kind of apply function:
SELECT apply_array(arr, sum) ...
SELECT apply_array(arr, avg) ...
Subqueries would probably be more SQL-like:
SELECT (SELECT sum(explode(arr))) ...
I don't think either of these should be within the scope of this KLIP though. I think we can consider this question closed for the purposes of this KLIP.

Would it not be possible to allow users to build their own UDAFs from lambdas by just providing a few build-in UDAFs called udaf:
-- Simple type:
-- col0: the input to aggregate
-- initial: initial agg value.
-- (col0, agg) => agg: the lambda that takes the current value and aggregate and calcs a new agg.
udaf(col0, initial, (col0, agg) => agg)

-- col0: the input to aggregate

udaf(col0, initial, (col0, m) => m, m => f)

I think you're right.
If we define the order of iteration of the entries in a MAP, then we could support the processing of a later entry overwriting a previous output entry, or support ignoring any subsequent results that clash with an existing key.
If we wish the SQL MAP type to be an unordered collection, choosing to keep either the first or last entry of a collisions would introduce nondeterminism. So we either say the result is undefined or we throw an exception, i.e. log an error and populate the result with NULL.
IMHO, we should keep the SQL MAP type an unordered collection, and of the two ways to handle key collisions when transforming an unordered MAP, the undefined result seems the lesser of two evils.
